Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Sea-level Variability over the Past 200,000 years Precisely Reconstructed from Carbonate Deposits in Mallorcan Caves
Award.AbstractNarration:
The researchers aim to construct a high resolution sea level curve for the western Mediterranean Basin as part of an effort to better understand global sea level variations. The island of Mallorca contains coastal caves that capture present and past sea level through the deposition of unique carbonate encrustations that form precisely at the sea level position.

The coastal caves of Mallorca were chosen for this study because of their demonstrated ability to obtain a high resolution sea-level history and the importance of the locality for addressing the issue of eustatic sea level change due to its unique tectonic and isostatic setting.

The results of the study will be of broad interest to a wide range of scientists interested in sea level variability and the vulnerability of ice sheets under a range of boundary conditions. The project will also foster strong collaborations among American and Spanish scientists and will support graduate and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Caves and their deposits are important contributors to sea-level studies. In particular, the phreatic overgrowths on speleothems (POS) from coastal caves of Mallorca (Spain) have been successfully used to reconstruct past sea-levels. Apart from generating a high resolution sea-level curve for the marine isotope stage (MIS) 5, one of the project's major outcome is that it documents (for the western Mediterranean basin) a remarkably stable sea-level at 2.25±0.75 m apsl between 126 and 116 ka, as well as rapid drops and rises around MIS-5a and MIS-5c. All of our sea level indicators above +3 mapsl were beyond U-series range in age, which is an indicator that sea level in this part of the Mediterranean basin did not likely go above +3 m during MIS-5e.  Our results provide the best high-resolution record of sea level thus far for the Last Interglacial period.

Summary of outcomes covering the entire life of the award

1. The results of a two-year geochemical study perfromed in two littoral caves of Mallorca provide insights into the deposition of POS, a valuable proxy for sea-level changes.

2. Completed a thorough study that characterized the mineralogical composition of the POS (and other minerals deposited near the sea-/brackish-water table) in Mallorca's largest littoral cave system (Vallgornera); on the basis of this information we inferred the relationship between cave development and sea-level changes.

3. Our study improved the resolution of the MIS 5 sea-level curve by adding 87 new U-series age results that directly (and indirectly) support our interpretations for the Last Interglacial sea level record in the western Mediterranean basin.

4. An additional 16 U-series results were not applicable to the MIS-5 sea level as the results indicate POS were precipitated during earlier sea-level high stands (beyond 150 ka). Furthermore, two POS samples were measured using U-Pb and the results suggest they formed as early as mid-Pliocene.

5. We used growth rate, δ13C, and δ18O of aragonite/calcite in a Mallorcan stalagmite that grew between 121 ka and present to document hydrogrologic changes (mainly changes in the source of precipitations). Precipitation amount in Mallorca appears to have been sensitive to proximal sea surface temperature variations. The record also shows that swings in the precipitation amounts, drier or wetter conditions are also associated with changes in the strength and position of the storm tracks carrying moisture from either the North Atlantic or Mediterranean Sea.
